@realmoney Mar 20, 2020 | 08:00 AM EDT DOUG KASS Market Friendly Developments? * Ns over Ss! * The lingering impact of COVID-19 on our behavior helps to explain my large long investments in Google, Amazon and Twitter

* Banks were the problem in the last recession, they will be part of the solution over the next few years Looking Forward * Tech and financials have my attention... here's why! Superior investment ideas today will be an outgrowth of the successful interpretation of the change

that is afoot - the lingering impact of COVID-19. For example, we will see a non trivial change in the usage of office space, the reduced importance of brick and mortar retail, and reduced airline travel. By contrast, we will likely see the proliferation and acceleration of

emerging trends in video conferencing, working at home, shopping on line, and in the demand for cloud services. That is why Alphabet ($GOOGL) , Amazon ($AMZN) and Twitter ($TWTR) are among my largest individual stock holdings. In other words, Ns (Nasdaq) over Ss (S&P)!

Finally, in The Great Decession of 2007-09 the banks were the problem - they were leveraged over 35-1, had concentrated (and risky) portfolios, had irresponsible managements, and distributed financial weapons of mass destruction with gusto. Today, banks will be part of the

solution of resuscitating domestic economic growth. With excess capital, extremely low leverage ratios (10-15:1), diversified loan portfolios, the best management teams (in history), generational low valuations and with interest rates likely to rise in the years ahead -

when combined with the stock price degradation over the last two months - the reward vs. risk is remarkably attractive now. ( ($JPM) , ($BAC) , ($C) , ($GS) , ($WFC) are my favorite names) @jimcramer @tomkeene @SquawkCNBC @cnbcfastmoney @Sarge986 @riskreversal @lizclaman

for helping states acquire out-of-stock protective gear. Trump said, “I am not a shipping clerk.” See Huffington Post, “Trump Dodges Accountability For Medical Supply Crisis By Blaming States.” The daily press briefings are worse than useless; they are harmful. Trump banned

Dr. Anthony Fauci from the daily press conferences after he repeatedly debunked Trump’s claims of miracle cures for Covid-19. See Slate, “Why Hasn’t Tony Fauci Been at the Coronavirus Press Conferences?” (“Fauci for the past two days had been saying that chloroquine is not a

miracle cure and that we still need to determine its safety.”) Until Trump allows medical professionals to run the press briefings, the daily briefings are a threat to the health and safety of all Americans. @jimcramer @tomkeene @riskreversal @ScottWapnerCNBC @andrewrsorkin

@realDonaldTrump Trump can no longer hold crazy campaign rallies, so he has hijacked the daily Coronavirus Task Force briefings where he holds “off-the-rails” news conferences. As a result, Trump is generating misinformation at a hectic pace, which makes it difficult for the

media to report the truth. For five minutes on Thursday, Americans believed that the FDA had approved a malaria drug as a treatment for Covid-19. Why? Because that is what Trump said during Thursday’s news conference. Five minutes later, the head of the FDA said that it had not

approved the malaria drug for Covid-19, and that approval was a “year away.” See Bloomberg, “Trump Touts Drug That FDA Says Isn’t Yet Approved for Virus.” The head of the World Health Organization said that “there is no proof that that is an effective treatment at this time.

We recommend that therapeutics be tested under ethically approved clinical trials to show efficacy and safety.” Trump was unfazed. He duped several news organizations—including Fox News—into promoting the false story in a headline. See Fox News, “Trump announces FDA making

anti-malaria drug available 'almost immediately' to tackle coronavirus.” It is no wonder that so many Fox News viewers believe the epidemic is overhyped. Fox News also ran this headline on Thursday evening, “Doctor says he's 3-4 weeks from treatment to 'neutralize' coronavirus.”

The body of the article says that the “doctor” is a few weeks away from giving his new treatment to a lab for initial evaluation before phase one clinical trials that may begin in July. In other words, don’t believe anything you hear from Trump until you read about his claims

in reputable sources. To similar effect is Trump’s “publicity stunt” yesterday in which he described himself as a “wartime president” and invoked the Defense Production Act. A day later, Trump admitted that he wasn’t going to use the limited authority granted to him in the

On Thursday I tweeted and wrote on @realmoney that we should be into "second level thinking:" The rising number of reported new cases in countries and the US that are just ramping up their testing is good news for the world and the markets because it means that widespread

testing is finally getting underway. Late last night I tweeted that the "safe at home" moves by California was very bullish for equities and would likely be soon followed by NY and other states. I continued to add to my net long exposure this week

in the belief that The Ackman Bottom (and times leading up to it) were providing unusual long opportunities - just as panic was intensifying. Pre coronavirus bulls had turned bears (True) fear and panic had escalated and stocks were remarkably cheap and put on sale. @jimcramer
